text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata with red rubrication and marginal plummet ruling

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf background reserved for the royal presence; deep blue mantles denote high status; red drapery provides visual contrast; white highlights on folds create subtle volume; alternating red and blue garments unify the composition; original pigments well preserved with minimal darkening

Hierarchical scaling with king larger than attendants
Figures overlap to suggest shallow spatial recession

drawing_technique.shading_method: Flat washes of color with minimal hatching and lead white highlights to model fabric
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling without linear perspective; shallow overlapping conveys limited depth

content_theme.scene_description: The miniature depicts a single scene: a crowned monarch seated on a simple bench-throne, holding a long cross-topped scepter in his left hand, his right hand raised to his chest in a gesture of assent. He wears a rose-pink robe beneath a purple mantle, and his golden crown is rendered in burnished leaf. Flanking him are six bearded male figures—three on his dexter and three on his sinister—each clad in red tunics and blue cloaks, with conical felt hats indicating official rank. The suppliants lean toward the king, their hands gesturing as if presenting a petition. The background is entirely covered with burnished gold leaf, isolating the event. Figures overlap in a compressed space, height differences and simple drapery folds indicate rank and spatial order. The border of alternating colored panels frames the action, directing focus to the central interaction.

secular: Six court officials in tunics and cloaks

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum with uniform thickness; flesh side prepared to a smooth finish; plummet ruling visible beneath illumination
technical_features.preservation_condition: Excellent; pigments vibrant with minimal flaking; gold leaf remains burnished; slight cockling at lower margin from early repair
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf background
Fine plume ruling for text and frame alignment

functional_analysis.intended_audience: Monastic chroniclers and secular patrons in a royal court context

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This miniature, likely produced in a Northern French workshop of the late 13th century, exemplifies the intersection of political propaganda and courtly historiography in medieval manuscripts. The strong Gothic textura script and precise border ornamentation reflect a well-established scriptorium tradition, while the refined use of ultramarine and vermilion signals a commission of high status. The scene’s centralized composition and hierarchical scaling underscore the monarch’s preeminence, mirroring contemporary notions of divine right. Technically, the application of raised gesso beneath burnished gold leaf denotes sophisticated studio practice, and the minimal yet purposeful white highlighting reveals a nuanced understanding of volume within a largely flat pictorial field. Iconographically, the six advisors’ identical gestures and attire emphasize collective counsel subordinate to royal will, conveying a message of unified governance under a strong sovereign. Comparatively, this image shares stylistic affinities with the Grandes Chroniques de France illuminations and may derive from parallel iconographic models seen in the Parisian ateliers of the Sainte-Chapelle. The manuscript thus functions both as a historical record and as a visual assertion of monarchical authority, bridging traditional medieval iconography with innovative pictorial emphasis on courtly ceremony and institutional power.
